title: This player asked for mid, then banned our mid's pick intent when they said no
body:
Is this reportable, given that the pre game chat isn't saved? Even worse, someone on enemy team dodged before the game started, thus cleaning up any evidence that this player did this.

In the remade lobby, the player did the same thing, but also stole the pick this time.

Third lobby, I (support) was queued with this player again, but without other players on my past team (presumably they just dodged and re-queued). The player got top again, but our mid was willing to swap.


Please tell me this is a reportable offense. I can provide the username privately if necessary (currently saved elsewhere, since I can't name and shame). I have no screenshots or other evidence, though.

This is not griefing. People are permitted to ban whoever they want for whatever reason they want.

for whatever reason? Does that include "this guy didn't give me the position I want, so I'll ban this guy's pick intent?"

I can understand banning declared intent in some situations, but "for whatever reason" seems too far.

Please show me the crystal ball that you have that can show you he wasn't already planning to ban that champ? Please tell me how you know the ONLY reason he banned it was because he couldn't trade lanes? 

EVEN if it was proven that he only did it because he couldn't trade lanes, he is permitted to ban whatever champ he chooses for whatever reason.
I mean he literally says he did it a second time with presumably a different midlaner. So that argument is invalid.

Same midlaner, actually. First time our mid hovered Zed, and our top banned Zed. Mid swapped to LeBlanc.
Next queue, our mid hovered LeBlanc, and our top banned LeBlanc instead. When the midlaner said they were planning to pick Zed anyway, the top picked Zed before mid got a chance to pick.

It's suspicious I grant you. But **none** of the things you describe are reportable or bannable.

If top decided they wanted to play Zed? Cool. If they decided they wanted to ban Zed? Cool. If they decided they wanted to ban LeBlanc? Cool. It's their right to do all of those things.

Pick and ban order exists for a reason. If he picked it before midlaner could, tough.

I mean, sure. They're allowed to do those specific things, just like picking Nunu and taking clarity and clairvoyance in champion select. But we can reasonably understand that the player is intentionally griefing.

It is literally impossible to determine intent over a videogame. That's why Riot requires in-game evidence of trolling/griefing before issuing a punishment.

With the current summoner spells, there are **very** few combinations that could be considered likely trolling, and even then they're not all cut/dry. It's very possible that clarity/clairvoyance would be a decent combo based on the enemy team.

You don't have a crystal ball, and just cause it makes you angry doesn't make it trolling. Just play the game, move on, and if you are so inclined report after the game if they actually troll during the game.

Also maybe work on the fact you seem to be getting so worked up over someone not treating your midlaner like the team captain who gets to do whatever they want.

Not sure why you think I'm getting worked up? I do think toxic players should be punished, but I don't think that's necessarily treating midlaners as team captains.

The example I showed was the infamous disco nunu. While yes, you technically don't know whether the Nunu will troll, you can reasonably assume that is the case. Same with the case I'm making here. Sure, it's technically possible that this guy actually meant to ban and pick those champions with good intentions, but you can reasonably assume that isn't the case based on their behavior.

The difference is that there is significant evidence in chat that the intention behind the ban was to target the "ally."

In the future, don't touch people's pick intents to better your own odds. You're banking on them being able to play another champion better than the champion they picked.

The odds you see on 3rd party sites is the _average_ win rate for that champion. The actual win rates for players who play that champion frequently are much _higher_, while the win rates for people playing champions for the first time is much, _much_ lower. If you ban Cait because she has a 48% win rate when the teammate who wanted to play her has a win rate closer to 55%, you've just taken the risk that your teammate also plays another adc _more_ successfully than the one they wanted to play, which usually results in you tanking your win rate, because people are most likely picking the champs they play the most.

Banning your teammate's pick intent to better your own win rate will _not_ work unless you ban a champ with a steep skill curve that someone on your team is very new to playing. Banning a first time Yasuo? Good idea if you care about your win rate. But randomly banning a teammate's champ because you perceive it to be a bad pick? Nope. Not only are you being a dick, but you're not doing your win rate any favors either.

Just thought I'd let you know that banning someone's pick intent to improve your win rate doesn't work, _except_ when they're learning a difficult champion, which is the specific case that you're against banning someone's pick intent. I'm against banning someone's pick intent for any reason, but in your case you didn't even gain anything from it. You blocked someone from playing Caitlynn so that they don't feed _as Caitlynn_ and you just ended up with the bot laner playing a champ that they're less experienced with. You denied someone the champ they wanted to play at the expense of your chances at winning. Nobody is better off in that situation.
Caitlyn mains have a 55% win rate. Banning the pick intent of someone in a population with a 55% win rate is detrimental to your win rate. End of discussion.
